comments.html:
Nmap has also a very useful command line option, which helps to understand, which packets the tool has sent/received. It's called --packet-trace. It shows you which packets, nmap is sending and which ones it has received, simmilar to the debug output.

Example:

nmap -sS -n -P0 -p 80 --packet-trace www.heise.de

Starting Nmap 4.20 ( http://insecure.org ) at 2007-06-13 12:42 Westeuropõische S
ommerzeit
SENT (0.5000s) TCP 10.1.3.131:48805 > 193.99.144.85:80 S ttl=53 id=21245 iplen=44 seq=1230587665 win=2048 mss 1460
RCVD (0.5160s) TCP 193.99.144.85:80 > 10.1.3.131:48805 SA ttl=247 id=41420 iplen=44 seq=2583668031 win=4182 ack=1230587666 mss 1394
Interesting ports on 193.99.144.85:
PORT STATE SERVICE
80/tcp open http

Nmap finished: 1 IP address (1 host up) scanned in 0.563 seconds

best regards,

Jochen
comments.name: Anonymous
